column1: #MichaelMartin	unknown-#MichaelMartin-party	unknown-#MichaelMartin-dob	unknown-#MichaelMartin-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2017-12-05 00:00:00	Leaders' Questions	0	Despite yesterday's setback and the inability to conclude the negotiations that would facilitate a movement to the next and most crucial phase of Brexit negotiations between the European Union and the United Kingdom
column2: I welcome the significant progress made in the form of the eventual wording that emerged yesterday which would commit all Governments and parties to not having a hard border between North and South in the aftermath of Brexit. I thank the Taoiseach for his briefings as well as his officials and the officials of the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade. While there was a lot of negativity articulated about civil servants last week
column3: let us acknowledge this week the diligent and very able work of our civil servants and diplomats in Brussels
column4: Dublin and London who
column5: since the Brexit vote
column6: have focused their energies loyally and intelligently on behalf of the State. When the vote for Brexit occurred
column7: all parties - the United Kingdom Government
column8: our EU partners
column9: unionists and nationalists in the North and the parties in this Oireachtas - were clear that there should be no hard border. Economic common sense and the desire to preserve and mind the Good Friday Agreement were central to this belief. However
column10: the fears and concerns of unionism need to be addressed. From the outset of the Brexit vote
column11: I have been at pains to separate the Brexit issue from the unity question. Others have sought to conflate the two. For me
column12: Brexit is about the economic well-being of all our communities on this island - the bread and butter of daily lives - and not
column13: as others advocated
column14: an opportunity to pursue a united Ireland through Border polls or otherwise.On reflection
column15: it must now be very clear to all that the contrived collapse of the Executive and the Assembly has not served the people of Northern Ireland well. It would have facilitated the articulation of different perspectives on Brexit in a democratically elected forum. In short
column16: it would have given a voice to the people of Northern Ireland on a most profound issue. Our agenda and that of the majority in the Oireachtas
column17: I believe
column18: is to limit the economic damage a hard Brexit would do to this island - nothing more and nothing less. The Good Friday Agreement upholds the constitutional status of Northern Ireland and the formula of words of yesterday copperfastens that status and does not undermine it. British–Irish relations are vital to our long-term economic well-being and we would do well to reflect this in our tone and demeanour from now until the Council meeting. Does the Taoiseach agree that the collapse of the Northern Ireland Executive and Assembly has been very damaging and that these institutions need to be restored as a matter of urgency
column19: particularly in the light of the ongoing negotiations? Does he accept that there needs to be an outreach to unionism that is deep and meaningful
column20: notwithstanding our differences on the issue? Does he agree that nothing in the formula of words or negotiations undermines the integrity of the constitutional status of Northern Ireland as part of the United Kingdom
column21: in accordance with the outcome of the referendum in 1998 and the Good Friday Agreement ?

column1: #LeoVaradkar	unknown-#LeoVaradkar-party	unknown-#LeoVaradkar-dob	unknown-#LeoVaradkar-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2017-12-05 00:00:00	Leaders' Questions	1	I acknowledge the considerable work done in recent weeks
column2: particularly over the weekend
column3: to seek an agreement. I refer to the work done by Ministers
column4: officials and diplomats in Dublin
column5: Brussels and elsewhere. I very much regret that it was not possible to conclude the deal yesterday
column6: as had been envisaged
column7: agreed and sequenced. The Government very much wants to move to phase 2. It does not want to hold things up. It is absolutely in our interests
column8: as a country
column9: to move to phase 2 because it is about the future trading relationship between the United Kingdom
column10: Ireland and the rest of the European Union. If one is an importer
column11: an exporter
column12: a farmer or a worker in the agrifood sector
column13: or if one's job depends on trade with the United Kingdom
column14: one wants to move to phase 2 and so do we. Phase 2 also deals with the transition period which is so important because it will give people and businesses time to prepare for any permanent change that might take place. It also deals with really important matters
column15: with aviation being just one example. It is a question of making sure planes can still fly and that airlines can agree schedules for the summer and autumn next year. We cannot move to phase 2
column16: however
column17: until we have the assurance we need that there will be no hard border and the assurances we have been promised for 18 months or even longer. As things stand
column18: the ball is very much in London's court. The Prime Minister
column19: the European Commission and the negotiating teams have asked for more time. We are happy that there should be more time. The European Council is not due to meet until Thursday of next week
column20: 14 December; therefore
column21: there is time to put the agreement back on track. I understand the Prime Minister is managing many difficulties in the United Kingdom. The European Union negotiates together with Ireland; we have the one negotiating team and that team is waiting to hear from London as soon as its team is ready to speak to us about events. With regard to the unionist community in Northern Ireland
column22: the Government and this Parliament respect the Good Friday Agreement in all its parts. We have no hidden agenda. We respect the constitutional status of Northern Ireland
column23: which is that Northern Ireland is part of the United Kingdom until a majority of the people in Northern Ireland say otherwise. We do not want there to be a border in the Irish Sea any more than we want there to be a border between Newry and Dundalk or between Letterkenny and Derry. Our aim has always been practical - to allow people to live their lives and carry out their business in the normal way in which they have done it for 20 years. I refer to cross-Border workers
column24: people involved in business
column25: traders
column26: exporters and students living in one jurisdiction and studying in the other. That has always been our objective. We were against Brexit in the first place because of the risk of the disruption that could be caused by it and the imposition of the Border. It is important not to forget to mention the nationalist community. I know that Deputy Micheál Martin did not deliberately forget to mention it
column27: but it is important that it be mentioned. We say to the nationalist community in Northern Ireland that we will protect its rights and freedoms and also protect the peace to which it is equally entitled to enjoy. We recognise that there is not just one political party in Northern Ireland; there are many. We will listen to
column28: respect and engage with all political parties in Northern Ireland.We will recognise the fact that the majority of people in Northern Ireland
column29: and the majority of constituencies in Northern Ireland
column30: did not vote to leave the European Union.

column1: #MichaelMartin	unknown-#MichaelMartin-party	unknown-#MichaelMartin-dob	unknown-#MichaelMartin-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2017-12-05 00:00:00	Leaders' Questions	2	I did reference nationalists at the very beginning of my remarks when I said no one on this island wanted a hard border
column2: including nationalism
column3: as articulated in Northern Ireland. I made the point in my question
column4: which the Taoiseach did not answer
column5: namely
column6: that the absence and contrived collapse of the Executive and the Assembly in Northern Ireland have not served the people of Northern Ireland well
column7: irrespective of the traditions from which they emanate or the political traditions that they represent. In fact
column8: if the Assembly were in place today there would be a majority in favour of remaining or against Brexit
column9: but the tragedy is that for the past 12 months that opinion has been silenced
column10: in many ways by the absence of a democratically elected forum in Northern Ireland. I have been saying that since the day it collapsed. Given the enormity of Brexit and its potential damage to Northern Ireland I do not understand that politicians could in my view contrive the collapse of that Executive and Assembly and allow it not to be restored over 12 months. The North-South Ministerial Council would have been a very useful conduit
column11: for example
column12: between the Government and elected Ministers from the North. Does the Taoiseach not think that has been a very significant damaging factor in all of this? It is interesting that Scotland
column13: London and Wales have all said they want the same type of agreement. What that illustrates is that there is a lot of opinion in the United Kingdom that does not favour a hard Brexit and I think it would be worth our while to reach out to that community in Britain who want a close relationship to Ireland and to the EU - in essence the equivalent of the customs union they currently enjoy.

column1: #LeoVaradkar	unknown-#LeoVaradkar-party	unknown-#LeoVaradkar-dob	unknown-#LeoVaradkar-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2017-12-05 00:00:00	Leaders' Questions	3	I agree that the absence of an Executive in Northern Ireland has been very unhelpful in the past year when we have been trying to secure a good agreement for Ireland and Northern Ireland. Before the Executive was collapsed there was an outline letter written by the First Minister
column2: Mrs. Foster
column3: and deputy First Minister
column4: Mr. McGuinness
column5: which set out principles which are not very different to what was agreed yesterday in Brussels
column6: and had the Executive remained in place it would have been possible to have a united cross-community elected voice for Northern Ireland
column7: which is not what we have had in the past year. People could be mistaken for thinking that one party spoke for all of Northern Ireland. In fact
column8: only the Executive elected and constituted under the Good Friday Agreement can speak legitimately for all of Northern Ireland. I agree with Deputy Martin's assessment. Perhaps if the Northern Ireland Assembly was meeting today it might even pass a resolution in favour of what was agreed
column9: as a majority of the people elected to that Assembly wanted to remain and the majority of the parties
column10: including the Alliance Party
column11: the Green Party
column12: the SDLP and others
column13: want to stay in the Internal Market and the customs union but
column14: unfortunately
column15: we have to deal with the situation as we find it. I know the days
column16: weeks and months that were spent trying to get the Executive up and running and to get the Assembly going. I know the enormous work the Tánaiste and Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade
column17: Deputy Coveney
column18: has done in that regard and also the previous Minister
column19: Deputy Flanagan
column20: prior to that. We have done everything possible to get the Executive and Assembly up and running while at the same time trying to handle Brexit negotiations. We will continue to do that. In terms of outreach to the unionist community and Northern parties
column21: that will continue. As Deputy Martin is aware
column22: not too long ago I spent an entire day in Enniskillen doing exactly that and that will continue. All members of the Government will continue our outreach to Northern Ireland and our business to Northern Ireland. The negotiations are taking place between a sovereign Government
column23: namely
column24: the United Kingdom on the one hand
column25: and the European Union
column26: of which we are part
column27: on the other. These are not negotiations involving one or any political party. This agreement
column28: if we come to it
column29: will be made between the UK Government on the one side and Europe and Ireland on the other. It will not involve one political party to the exclusion of others. That would not be right.

column1: #GerryAdams	unknown-#GerryAdams-party	unknown-#GerryAdams-dob	unknown-#GerryAdams-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2017-12-05 00:00:00	Leaders' Questions	4	Everything I say must be taken in the context that Sinn Féin has not seen the text of the deal which the Taoiseach outlined yesterday. I thank him for the briefings. Tá Sinn Féin buíoch don Taoiseach
column2: don Tánaiste agus dá gcuid oifigigh. The Taoiseach should also know that Downing Street is briefing today that the text was not finalised
column3: that those involved were still going back and forth and that the British Prime Minister did not have enough to go to her Cabinet
column4: agus tá sé sin mar eolas don Taoiseach
column5: b'fhéidir. From the very beginning
column6: Sinn Féin has said that what is required is a designated special status for the North within the European Union. We are not precious about what it is called but we are certain that any deal must ensure that the North remains within the customs union and the Single Market. That is the only way of ensuring stability and certainty for Irish agriculture and business as well as Irish people's lives
column7: prospects and prosperity. That is not the only issue. Citizens' rights
column8: access to the European Court of Justice and access to European institutions needs to be firmly bedded down. As I understand it
column9: those matters have yet to be agreed. Ensuring that these requirements are met is common sense. It is also
column10: crucially
column11: what the people of the North voted for. Despite the claims of the DUP
column12: this will not change the constitutional position of the North. I say as much as someone who is offended every day by the divisions on this island
column13: including the Border and partition. We have always said that the Tory deal with the DUP would end in tears. However
column14: we should also not underestimate the consequences of that deal. It has been played out in Stormont in recent times and yesterday in Brussels. More enlightened members of the DUP know that a special arrangement needs to be struck for the North. They know that this is not a case of orange versus green. Yet
column15: we should not underestimate the contrariness of some of their leaders. Despite this
column16: all of us who live on this island collectively
column17: including the DUP
column18: must protect each other and plan intelligently for a future for everyone. I genuinely wish the Taoiseach and the Tánaiste and Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade
column19: Deputy Coveney
column20: all the best in their endeavours in the run-up to the meeting of the European Council on 14 December. However
column21: let us be clear: no matter how diplomatically the Taoiseach may have to put it
column22: his Government needs to stand up against the narrow interests of the DUP and the English Tories. It is about getting the best deal for all of the people of the island of Ireland. Can the Taoiseach guarantee that his Government will not accept any deal that does not ensure the North remains within the customs union and the Single Market? Can the Taoiseach guarantee that his Government will not accept any agreement that does not have the legal and political infrastructure of the Good Friday Agreement hardwired into it?

column1: #LeoVaradkar	unknown-#LeoVaradkar-party	unknown-#LeoVaradkar-dob	unknown-#LeoVaradkar-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2017-12-05 00:00:00	Leaders' Questions	5	The text was agreed by the negotiation teams on both sides yesterday morning and was confirmed to me in telephone calls with the EU Commission President
column2: Mr. Juncker
column3: and the European Council President
column4: Mr. Tusk
column5: during the morning as well. It was only during the lunch that we got information that a problem had arisen. It is always the case with these agreements that nothing is agreed until everything is agreed and signatures are on the dotted line. In any event that would not have happened until 14 December
column6: which is Thursday of next week. Even if it had been the case that the deal had been agreed in the way we had envisaged it would be yesterday
column7: it is possible that it would still be falling apart today - we need to be realistic about that. Nonetheless
column8: the ball is very much in London's court. We are here to work constructively on behalf of the European Union and Ireland with the UK Government to come to an agreement based on the principles that we had agreed to
column9: at least in principle
column10: yesterday. It is important to talk about the kind of agreement that we believed was in place. First of all
column11: it would be one that defends all parts of the Good Friday Agreement and its successor agreements. It is one that would continue to ensure everyone born in Northern Ireland could continue to be a British and Irish citizen and
column12: therefore
column13: a citizen of the European Union. Thus it would allow people in Northern Ireland
column14: for example
column15: people born in Belfast and Derry
column16: to study in Paris
column17: if they wished
column18: to travel to Athens and to work in Madrid. People born in Sheffield and Leeds are giving up that right by leaving the European Union. It would protect the common travel area between Britain and Ireland
column19: which is about so much more than us being able to travel freely between Britain and Ireland. It comes with a whole set of reciprocal citizens' rights and the fact that British and Irish people can live
column20: work and study as well as access health care
column21: housing
column22: education
column23: welfare and pensions in each other's countries as though we were citizens of both. We had that agreed too. We also agreed that INTERREG and PEACE funding
column24: which are so important for Border areas
column25: would continue through to 2020 and 2021 and be favourably considered for the period thereafter. We agreed a solution that we still believe allows us to keep the Border open to trade between North and South.This solution is that there would not be a hard border and there would be no physical infrastructure. This would be assured in one of three ways
column26: namely
column27: in the end EU-UK new trade agreement
column28: through bespoke solutions that the British Government would come up with or
column29: if all else failed
column30: the UK assuring that regulatory alignment would be continued between Northern Ireland and the European Union. One of these three ways is also one about which the UK Government and those who support Brexit want to talk. By refusing this agreement
column31: the UK Government has made it impossible to talk about the technical solutions it believes could solve our problem. Having asked us for many months to start engaging in options as to how we can avoid a hard border
column32: it has now decided it does not want to have that conversation simply because we have asked that there be a backstop that assures us that in all circumstances there will not be a border with Northern Ireland.  What is interesting
column33: and it has been picked up on by other speakers
column34: is that the agreement we believed we had yesterday and still believe we have
column35: although obviously it has not been ratified
column36: is one which
column37: within hours
column38: was being identified by people in Scotland
column39: Wales and London as an agreement that they too would like. Even people in England
column40: both on the remain and leave sides
column41: have been saying in the past day that perhaps they would like such an arrangement for all of the United Kingdom. It is a remarkable turn of events in that regard. I believe
column42: and this is the most important thing
column43: that the majority of people in Northern Ireland
column45: would like to have this agreement.

column1: #GerryAdams	unknown-#GerryAdams-party	unknown-#GerryAdams-dob	unknown-#GerryAdams-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2017-12-05 00:00:00	Leaders' Questions	6	Sinn Féin consistently argued that the negotiations should not move to the next phase unless there was movement on the three outstanding issues. We
column2: therefore
column3: support the Government's position in not moving into that phase. What I outlined to the Taoiseach earlier is what Downing Street is briefing today. I am not saying it is telling the truth but simply that this is what it is briefing. The Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade correctly stated that Ireland cannot afford to take a leap into the dark. The only way to avoid doing that is to have absolute clarity and certainty on the entire island staying in the customs union and Single Market. This is about more than trade
column4: although trade is obviously important. Does the Taoiseach agree - as I understand it
column5: this was not part of the deal he outlined yesterday - that citizens' rights and access to the European Court of Justice and other European Union institutions need to be a central part of any agreement? If so
column6: this needs to be a central plank in his negotiations as otherwise the Good Friday Agreement will be destroyed. The Taoiseach must not let that happen on his watch.

column1: #LeoVaradkar	unknown-#LeoVaradkar-party	unknown-#LeoVaradkar-dob	unknown-#LeoVaradkar-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2017-12-05 00:00:00	Leaders' Questions	7	To clarify what I said earlier
column2: what we agreed yesterday was the whole text
column3: not just principles. We agreed principles and a detailed text and we had confirmation of that from President Juncker and President Tusk to whom I spoke last night. The principles and the basic outcome that we want are shared by all parties in this House and I am encouraged by and grateful for the support we have received from Fianna Fáil
column4: Sinn Féin and the other parties. We know what needs to be achieved and we are waiting to hear from London as to how it wishes to proceed. There will be contacts in the coming days to see if there is a possibility of putting this agreement back on track before the European Council meets on Thursday and Friday next. I am reassured by today's statement from the European Commission and the task force that Ireland's position is Europe's position and that Europe stands with Ireland.

column1: #BrendanHowlin	unknown-#BrendanHowlin-party	unknown-#BrendanHowlin-dob	unknown-#BrendanHowlin-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2017-12-05 00:00:00	Leaders' Questions	8	Long before the Brexit referendum
column2: it was clear that Brexit presented a mortal threat to the soft border between Ireland and Northern Ireland and the peace process that had been built up by so many people over many decades. The Labour Party has consistently supported the position adopted by the Government on the commitment required by the people of this island from the British Government to ensure Brexit does the minimum possible damage to the hard won political and economic stability on this island. We do so in full recognition of the rejection of Brexit by the people of Northern Ireland. Unfortunately
column3: as we are all well aware
column4: the consequences of Brexit on the Border were not central to the Brexit debate in the United Kingdom
column5: that is
column6: until now.Yesterday
column7: we were on the verge of a significant breakthrough. Months of extensive work
column8: lobbying and networking - I
column9: too
column10: pay tribute to our officials - with our colleagues in Europe had reached a critical point. Patient efforts to build a consensus on the Irish issues
column11: to get people who did not really understand them to be fully apprised of them
column12: to unite the 26 countries of the EU behind the Irish position and to find a practical solution acceptable to the UK had
column13: we believed
column14: borne fruit. The final agreement came down to a debate on the difference between no regulatory divergence versus ongoing regulatory alignment. I said to the Taoiseach last week that what we needed was Ireland to act collectively in regard to this. Little did I know that it was the UK that would fail to act collectively. Despite the position of the DUP being that it officially opposes a hard border
column15: it has offered no solutions to achieve that objective. What it is prepared to do is to say
column16: "No". What has shocked me and many others from the middle of yesterday is the failure of the British Government and the Prime Minister
column17: Mrs. May
column18: to ensure that the constituent parts of her own Government and the United Kingdom were on board with what was being agreed. I spoke to my colleagues in the British Labour Party yesterday evening. They were also at a loss as to how such a defeat could be snatched from the jaws of victory. The Brexit demons that have plagued political discourse in the UK have been unfortunately unleashed again. The solution to this problem is obvious and involves the UK as a whole accepting the need to remain within the Single Market and the customs union
column19: a position
column20: as others have instanced
column21: that has now been accepted by
column22: among others
column23: Wales
column24: Scotland and London. While this morning the leader of the Conservative Party in Scotland has called for ongoing regulatory alignment for the entire UK
column25: exiting the Single Market and the customs union was not determined by the British referendum. There was a political decision made by the British Government to do that
column26: and the outstanding question now is what the British Government will be able to agree to. I have a number of questions. Our relationship with the UK had reached a peak of strength in recent years. I believe it has been significantly damaged in very recent times. Having formally agreed a position that collapsed over lunch yesterday
column27: how can we as a country now negotiate with the United Kingdom in good faith and how stands the credibility of the negotiating forum when carefully negotiated words can be unpicked after the fact?

column1: #LeoVaradkar	unknown-#LeoVaradkar-party	unknown-#LeoVaradkar-dob	unknown-#LeoVaradkar-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2017-12-05 00:00:00	Leaders' Questions	9	I will pick up on one or two points. There was an exchange of text including different options
column2: one being no regulatory divergence and the other being regulatory alignment. On Sunday night
column3: we were satisfied that we could accept either of those sets of words and regulatory alignment was what was accepted by the British negotiators on Monday morning. We have also agreed a mechanism which
column4: I think
column5: should allow us to move on to phase 2. We all - the DUP in Northern Ireland
column6: all the parties here
column7: all the parties in the North
column8: the British Government
column9: both Remainers and Brexiteers - say we want to avoid a hard border and have no physical infrastructure. How do we achieve that? The agreement that we had yesterday set out three possible options. The first
column10: my preferred option and the preferred option of most Members in this House
column11: is an EU-UK free trade agreement that would allow free trade to continue
column12: not only North-South but between Britain and Ireland. Second
column13: an option which those who have been advocates of Brexit have always said was a possibility
column14: is a bespoke arrangement involving technology and other things about which we are sceptical but we are willing to allow for consideration. Third
column15: and crucially
column16: is a backstop
column17: if all else failed
column18: of ongoing regulatory alignment between North and South. I do not see how we can proceed and how we can achieve what anybody wants to achieve unless we allow ourselves to go on to phase 2 on that basis. We are keen to move on to phase 2 but we must have the assurance we were promised that
column19: no matter what
column20: even as an unintended consequence
column21: there will not be a hard border on the island of Ireland. We have to hold firm on that position. In terms of relations with the United Kingdom
column22: Deputy Howlin is correct. Relations were probably at their peak since independence around the time of the Queen's visit and the years after that. Relations had been strained in the past year or two
column23: not because of a decision we made but because of Brexit
column24: which is a British policy and a British decision
column25: one that we respect but that we are aware causes enormous problems
column26: not only for us but for others in Europe as well.Nonetheless
column27: I am very firmly of the view that the Prime Minister
column28: Mrs. May
column29: is negotiating in good faith and that her team
column30: who agreed the language of the EU task force on Monday
column31: were negotiating in good faith. They have asked for more time and we are happy to allow them to have that time and we look forward to hearing from them as to how they now believe we can proceed with this agreement.

column1: #BrendanHowlin	unknown-#BrendanHowlin-party	unknown-#BrendanHowlin-dob	unknown-#BrendanHowlin-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2017-12-05 00:00:00	Leaders' Questions	10	However disappointed all of us are at the turn of events yesterday
column2: obviously we are all now required to look forward and not back. Has the Taoiseach had discussions with Michel Barnier since the events of noon yesterday? Has he ascertained his position as the mandated negotiator on behalf of the EU 27? How can Mr. Barnier and his negotiating team sit down and negotiate to a conclusion a form of words
column3: set up a carefully organised series of events involving the Prime Minister of the United Kingdom
column4: Mr. Jean-Claude Juncker
column5: the EU Council President
column6: Mr. Donald Tusk
column7: the Irish Government and others and have all of that fall apart? The Taoiseach has said that the ball is now in London's court. What specifically can we do
column8: as one of the EU 27
column9: to ensure that we move on to the next phase of negotiations
column10: while safeguarding the fundamental principles that we
column11: as a House
column12: have set out as our requirements for the conclusion of phase 1?

column1: #LeoVaradkar	unknown-#LeoVaradkar-party	unknown-#LeoVaradkar-dob	unknown-#LeoVaradkar-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2017-12-05 00:00:00	Leaders' Questions	11	We operate a particular line of communications. As Deputy Howlin knows
column2: Mr. Barnier heads up the Barnier negotiating task force but that is a creature of the Commission. The Barnier task force reports to the Commission and to the President of the Commission. When I speak to an interlocutor
column3: I speak to the President of the Commission
column4: Mr. Juncker as my counterpart in the set up and also to the President of the Council
column5: Mr. Tusk. The Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade
column6: Deputy Coveney
column7: mainly deals with Michel Barnier and his task force
column8: which includes a Sherpa who speaks to our Sherpa. That is the line of communications that exists
column9: with which the Deputy will be familiar. I spoke to President Juncker twice yesterday; once in the morning to confirm our acceptance of the language and once yesterday evening
column10: after things had gone somewhat pear shaped. In our latter conversation he confirmed his ongoing support for the Irish position and asked that we continue to trust him in the negotiations
column11: which we absolutely do. I know that he has cancelled a planned overseas visit so that the essential EU officials can be available for further talks in Brussels in the coming days. We are at the point now where the UK Government is trying to sort out its own affairs and when it has done so it will come back to Brussels for further negotiations. We will be in daily contact with the task force and with President Juncker.

column1: #RuthCoppinger	unknown-#RuthCoppinger-party	unknown-#RuthCoppinger-dob	unknown-#RuthCoppinger-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2017-12-05 00:00:00	Leaders' Questions	12	I would like to bring the Taoiseach's attention back to our other national crisis
column2: the housing crisis. Homelessness is at record levels
column3: the price of a house has risen by 50% since 2013 and rents continue to sky-rocket despite the Government's ineffectual rent pressure zones. This Government and its predecessor have treated the housing crisis like some strange
column4: mysterious phenomenon for which we must go on a quest to find solutions but it is actually quite simple. Public house building has ground to a halt; it was slashed to bail out billionaires ten years ago and it has never been restarted. Local authorities own more than 1
column5: 200 ha of land with the potential for 38
column6: 000 houses but less than 1% of the social housing that is needed has been built on that land. Housing analyst Mr. Mel Reynolds said that it is a policy decision not to build on local authority land and that the State is actually the biggest land hoarder in this country. To hoard land during a housing crisis is akin to hoarding food in a famine. A total of 13 councils did not bother to build a solitary thing in the last two years. Fingal County Council
column7: with which the Taoiseach will be familiar
column8: completed ten homes. Ten homes equates to 0.01% of the number needed for the 8
column9: 046 people on its housing list. The Fingal area has 22% of Dublin's population but 35% of its homeless population
column10: mostly in the Taoiseach's own constituency and mine
column11: Dublin West.It is a microcosm of the national housing crisis. Solidarity has put forward a proposal to council management to build on its own land. In Blanchardstown the council has 75 acres of zoned land that it has never developed at Damastown. Solidarity has taken drone footage
column12: got architects drawings
column13: made a video
column14: produced a booklet and costed a proposal to provide over 1

column2: I do not agree with the Deputy about rent pressure zones. They are far from perfect but I believe they are working. Some 60% of people in tenancies are now covered by rent pressure zones and

column8: as the Deputy knows. These are new tenancies and new rents
column9: and they do not take full account of the 60% of people who are covered and protected by the rent pressure zones - the existing tenants. The rent pressure zones were designed to cap rent increases to protect people who had tenancies on their homes
column10: and they are working in that regard. They were never designed for new tenancies and do not apply to them. In terms of social housing and public housing

column17: when we get the final figures

column20: more houses and homes will have been built in the country than in any year since 2010. Therefore
column21: we are starting to see

column24: if the Deputy prefers - and private housing. The number of directly built social homes this year will be around 2
column25: 000 and that will rise to 3
column26: 800 next year. We can add to that those that are not directly built by local authorities

column34: if she sees no good

column1: #ClareDaly	unknown-#ClareDaly-party	unknown-#ClareDaly-dob	unknown-#ClareDaly-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2017-12-05 00:00:00	Leaders' Questions	27	I have always operated on the basis of co-operation at the Business Committee and the expediency of delivering the business to which this House needs to attend
column2: but this is a departure from anything I have seen. I was the first person to raise at the Business Committee a number of weeks ago that the Dáil should be provided with adequate time to discuss this vital matter. I was assured that this would be the case. I know that in subsequent weeks Members of the House across the different political groupings have raised the issue. Last week the Tánaiste stated its scheduling was a matter for the Business Committee
column3: but it did not discuss the issue on Thursday. Not only was it not discussed in the context of this week's business
column4: it was also not mentioned by the Government in the context of next week's business either. This is an incredibly serious matter that potentially signs up the State to massive defence expenditure in the next few years. The proposal is that we have 15 minutes for each group shoehorned into a Thursday session on the eve of the recess. It is completely unacceptable and I object to it in the strongest possible terms.

column1: #AengusOSnodaighSF	unknown-#AengusOSnodaighSF-party	unknown-#AengusOSnodaighSF-dob	unknown-#AengusOSnodaighSF-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2017-12-05 00:00:00	Leaders' Questions	28	Similar to the previous Deputies
column2: I object in the strongest terms to the way this matter has appeared on the schedule for this week. As has been noted
column3: there was no discussion about it in any shape or form at last week's meeting of the Business Committee. Deputy Seán Crowe and I discussed it as a Topical Issue only a few weeks ago when it was indicated that the Government might sign up to it and that it was aware of the deadlines. All of a sudden
column4: it appeared on the schedule for discussion on Thursday. The proposal is that we have two hours in which to make a decision.We are to be given only two hours to debate an EU proposal that would lead to a major shift in Irish foreign
column5: defence and financial policy. It has not been discussed in committee and has been subject to no scrutiny in the newspapers or by the public generally. Two hours is way too short a timeframe to deal with the implications of such a significant move and it behoves us to ensure adequate time is allocated. Indeed the proposal should have gone beyond this House. It certainly should
column6: at the very least
column7: have been discussed at committee. As I understand it
column8: the detail of the proposal has not been circulated to any Member. All we have been told is that the EU proposals for permanent structured defence co-operation are to be discussed for two hours this Thursday. That is a disgrace given the huge commitments involved. We are talking about a requirement
column9: very shortly after signing up to the agreement
column10: for a threefold increase in defence spending. Given the other crises we are facing-----

column3: as such
column4: we should be given more time to debate it. Perhaps the Business Committee might meet later today to discuss how that can be facilitated.

column1: #BrendanHowlin	unknown-#BrendanHowlin-party	unknown-#BrendanHowlin-dob	unknown-#BrendanHowlin-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2017-12-05 00:00:00	Leaders' Questions	32	Any matter that impinges on defence is a matter of great sensitivity for the Members of this House and
column2: more importantly
column3: for the people of this country. We all engaged in a great deal of introspection immediately after the initial defeat of the referendum on the Lisbon treaty. One of the things that became evident at that time was the need for mechanisms in this House to accommodate proper debate such that people can understand proposals in full measure. Whatever one's point of view on a particular issue
column4: there should always be facilitation of a full debate. The idea was that we would have a robust committee system in the House whereby people would be invited in to give evidence
column5: the proceedings would be broadcast
column6: and this House would subsequently come to an informed decision on the matter in question. Will the Taoiseach
column7: who is also the Minister for Defence
column8: accept the view expressed by so many Deputies in the House today that we should have a proper committee debate on these matters? There is no rush to sign up to the proposals this side of Christmas. I understand there is a request to do so
column9: but we may choose to postpone our signing up until after the event. We must have a proper debate
column10: with experts invited in and cross-examined
column11: after which the House can come to an informed decision. It would be entirely improper to sanction these proposals on the basis of a two-hour debate in which 15 minutes is allocated to each group.

column1: #SeamusHealy	unknown-#SeamusHealy-party	unknown-#SeamusHealy-dob	unknown-#SeamusHealy-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2017-12-05 00:00:00	Leaders' Questions	33	I agree with the concerns expressed by previous speakers. We are seeing an attempt to bulldoze a very significant provision through the House without adequate debate. In fact
column2: not only do we need debate in this House
column3: there also must be widespread public debate on the issue. To proceed as proposed would be hugely damaging to our neutrality and result in its further erosion. It would commit the country to expenditure in this area of 2% per annum
column4: which is some €3 billion. Given the serious issues facing our health
column5: housing and other areas of provision
column6: we should not even be contemplating expenditure of that level on this proposal. The notification for the debate is totally inadequate. There must be full public scrutiny
column7: in this House
column8: in the media and among the public. The matter should be deferred at least until 31 March 2018 to allow for that debate to take place.

column1: #LeoVaradkar	unknown-#LeoVaradkar-party	unknown-#LeoVaradkar-dob	unknown-#LeoVaradkar-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2017-12-05 00:00:00	Leaders' Questions	72	I would like to lead the House in paying tribute to the former Chief Justice
column2: Thomas Finlay
column3: who died at the weekend and was buried today. Over the course of 50 years he made an extraordinary contribution to the law in Ireland in a life devoted to public service. We should also remember that Mr. Justice Finlay served in the Dáil with great distinction in the 1950s. He was an eloquent representative of the people of Dublin South-Central.Throughout his distinguished career
column4: he always showed great sensitivity and skill
column5: whether chairing the tribunal which investigated the hepatitis C scandal
column6: or delivering the landmark judgment in the X case. As Chief Justice
column7: his guiding focus was the vindication of the rights of the citizen and he was praised
column8: for example
column9: for the humane way in which he approached family law cases involving children. Like all good people
column10: he wore his goodness lightly and he was known for his humility and kindness as well as his fierce intellect. Our sympathies are with his family and friends
column11: including his daughter
column12: Mrs Justice Mary Finlay Geoghegan
column13: who was appointed to the Supreme Court last month. Today we honour a servant of the State
column14: whose greatest virtue was his absolute fairness in the administration of justice.

#MichaelMartin	unknown-#MichaelMartin-party	unknown-#MichaelMartin-dob	unknown-#MichaelMartin-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2017-12-05 00:00:00	Leaders' Questions	77	I appreciate the Ceann Comhairle's difficulty but we got a phone call to suggest this was happening. Ar mo shon féin agus ar son mo pháirtí
column2: ba mhaith liom mo chomhbhrón a dhéanamh le clann Thomas Finlay. Is léir dúinn go ndearna sé an-chuid ar son an Stáit. Bhí sé dílis do mhuintir na tíre. He had a long life and achieved many great things during it. He made some fundamental judgments. One of the most significant was the Attorney General v. Hamilton in which the Supreme Court held that the confidentiality of Cabinet discussions was absolute. I know that is a principle that current members of the Cabinet hold very dear indeed. He also ruled in Attorney General v. Hamilton (No. 2) in 1993 about parliamentary privilege. It was an important ruling where the Supreme Court held that Deputies are not amenable to any legal process with regard to utterances they make in the Dáil. Some fundamental judgments were made relating to this House
column3: the role of Cabinet and our overall Government architecture. He gave the leading judgment in the controversial X case. He worked
column4: as the Taoiseach said
column5: on the hepatitis C tribunal of inquiry. To sum up
column6: he left an enduring legacy of public service and
column7: as a Member of this House
column8: both politically and subsequently
column9: in developing jurisprudence
column10: he made a remarkable contribution to Irish life and I express our sympathies to his family
column11: particularly to the recently appointed Supreme Court judge
column12: Mrs Justice Mary Finlay Geoghegan.

column1: #GerryAdams	unknown-#GerryAdams-party	unknown-#GerryAdams-dob	unknown-#GerryAdams-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2017-12-05 00:00:00	Leaders' Questions	78	Ar mo shon féin agus ar son Shinn Féin
column2: ba mhaith liom comhbhrón a dhéanamh le clann Thomas Finlay
column3: iarPhríomh-Bhreitheamh agus Teachta Dála
column4: a fuair bás dé Domhnaigh. Go ndéana Dia trócaire air. Ní raibh aithne agam ar an Uasal Finlay. I did not know Mr. Justice Finlay. However
column5: he had a long and distinguished career in public office and it is clear from the many expressions of sympathy that he was a hugely respected figure
column6: both as a former Fine Gael Deputy
column7: a member of the Bar
column8: and consequently and subsequently as a Supreme Court judge and Chief Justice
column9: and a member of the Council of State. I want to extend my sympathies and the sympathies of Sinn Féin to his family
column10: especially his children
column11: including Mrs Justice Mary Finlay Geoghegan who was recently appointed to the Supreme Court. Ar dheis Dé go raibh a anam.

column1: #BrendanHowlin	unknown-#BrendanHowlin-party	unknown-#BrendanHowlin-dob	unknown-#BrendanHowlin-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2017-12-05 00:00:00	Leaders' Questions	79	With the Ceann Comhairle's permission
column2: I would like to express my sympathy to the family and friends of those involved in the horrific road traffic accident that occurred in my own constituency of Wexford
column3: on the New Ross road
column4: last night. I empathise with the emergency response personnel
column5: the gardaí and the ambulance crews
column6: and indeed local people who arrived on what was a scene of horror. I echo the words of the Taoiseach and other leaders in extending our condolences to the family
column7: friends and former colleagues of former Chief Justice
column8: Thomas Finlay. His career was exemplified
column9: as others have said
column10: by distinguished public service. He served the people both as a representative in this Parliament and as an arbiter of justice.As others have said
column11: in his career he was central to some of the most far-reaching judicial decisions of our time. He delivered the leading judgment in the X case and upheld parliamentary privilege in the beef tribunal case against the former leader of the Labour Party
column12: Mr. Dick Spring. Even in retirement
column13: he continued to serve
column14: including as a sole member of the hepatitis C tribunal. On behalf of the Labour Party
column15: I send our sympathy and condolences to his extended family.

column1: #MichaelMartin	unknown-#MichaelMartin-party	unknown-#MichaelMartin-dob	unknown-#MichaelMartin-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2017-12-05 00:00:00	Leaders' Questions	81	I have raised with the Taoiseach on a number of occasions during Leaders' Questions and the Order of Business the outstanding moneys that are owed to what are termed section 39 agencies. These include hospices throughout the country and many disability organisations. There is an incontrovertible link between HSE pay scales and the pay scales of employees in those organisations. They were told
column2: and there is a documentary trail
column3: that they were to implement the FEMPI cuts to pay when those cuts happened. Now they are being denied the necessary funding from the Department in respect of restoration of pay as per the new public service pay agreements. This is very unfair and the State is being very cynical in its treatment of hospices and other section 39 bodies. Tomorrow we will have the health Estimates and the health service plan is due next week. The Taoiseach has indicated that he would examine the situation. Will he confirm that tomorrow's Estimates will provide for funding to cover pay restoration for these agencies' employees?

column1: #LeoVaradkar	unknown-#LeoVaradkar-party	unknown-#LeoVaradkar-dob	unknown-#LeoVaradkar-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2017-12-05 00:00:00	Leaders' Questions	82	I cannot confirm at this stage whether it is covered by the Estimates but the Minister for Finance
column2: Deputy Paschal Donohoe
column3: and the Minister for Health
column4: Deputy Simon Harris
column5: are working through the issue. As is often the case
column6: things are perhaps not as straightforward as they may appear. They discovered that some section 39 organisations reduced pay in line with the FEMPI legislation but others did not. Some were compliant with public sector pay rules but others were not. For example
column7: they were paying some of their senior staff salaries over and above what was allowed under public sector pay rules and this has created a degree of difficulty. However
column8: it is intended that the Minister for Finance and the Minister for Health will work through it as quickly as possible to identify those who were compliant with public sector pay rules and applied the FEMPI cuts and those who did not and to examine whether they have been given an adequate increase to cover that.

column1: #GerryAdams	unknown-#GerryAdams-party	unknown-#GerryAdams-dob	unknown-#GerryAdams-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2017-12-05 00:00:00	Leaders' Questions	83	Tá ceist agam faoin UN Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities and the Disability (Miscellaneous Provisions) Bill 2016. When I raised this issue with the Taoiseach in September
column2: he said it was the Government's intention to ratify the UN convention by the end of the year and preferably by 3 December
column3: which was the International Day of Persons with Disabilities
column4: but that date has passed without ratification. This morning the media reported that the Minister of State with responsibility for disability issues
column5: Deputy Finian McGrath
column6: who told us a year and a half ago that it would be ratified within six months
column7: was going to Cabinet to ask for an intensification of efforts to do what was promised in September. Will the Taoiseach clarify the outcome of this morning's discussions and his current expectation on ratification?

column1: #LeoVaradkar	unknown-#LeoVaradkar-party	unknown-#LeoVaradkar-dob	unknown-#LeoVaradkar-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2017-12-05 00:00:00	Leaders' Questions	84	The Deputy will be pleased to know that we are making good progress in this area. We agreed at Cabinet this morning to publish the heads of the Bill on deprivation of liberty. This was one of the next big steps to be taken to allow us to ratify the convention. Cabinet did not get all of its business done this morning so we will reconvene this afternoon. I anticipate that
column2: as a consequence
column3: the Minister of State
column4: Deputy McGrath
column5: will be able to make a positive statement with regard to our ratification of the UN Convention for Persons with Disabilities. I hope we will be able to make that statement in the next couple of days.

column1: #BrendanHowlin	unknown-#BrendanHowlin-party	unknown-#BrendanHowlin-dob	unknown-#BrendanHowlin-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2017-12-05 00:00:00	Leaders' Questions	85	On the same matter
column2: the Taoiseach will be aware that the Disability (Miscellaneous Provisions) Bill passed Second Stage in February. It has been on Committee Stage for nine months. For nine months
column3: we have been awaiting the very thing he has now announced
column4: which is for the Minister of State to bring forward amendments that were promised. When various Members of this House raised the ratification of the convention
column5: we were repeatedly told that
column6: unlike other countries
column7: we do not ratify until all the legislation is in place. The weekend press said that we will have a sort of fake ratification
column8: that is
column9: we would do it in advance of legislation. I
column10: therefore
column11: have two very simple questions for the Taoiseach. Will he confirm that the position held by successive Governments that
column12: in order that they have a meaningful signing
column13: we do not ratify UN conventions until all the legislation provision is in place still holds? Will the Minister of State bring to this House the amendments to deal with the legislative barrier to final ratification before Christmas? I think the Taoiseach will find a willingness across the House to sit on a Monday or whenever the Government might need to do this so that we can formally ratify the convention by the end of this year.

#RichardBoydBarrett	unknown-#RichardBoydBarrett-party	unknown-#RichardBoydBarrett-dob	unknown-#RichardBoydBarrett-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2017-12-05 00:00:00	Leaders' Questions	87	For the umpteenth time
column2: the Taoiseach has again today referred to his commitment to social mix in terms of housing. This has been the justification for the
column3: in effect
column4: privatisation plans for approximately 800 publicly owned sites. Up to 60% of those sites will be
column5: in effect
column6: privatised. On the Part V private development requirement to give over 10% for public housing and social mix
column7: is the Taoiseach aware that we received a report on Dún Laoghaire where only three out of eight of the Part V proposals since the legislation was brought in are actually getting that social mix. column8: will the Government do anything to tighten up the legislation to ensure that private developers of private developments do not get to shove social housing off-site
column9: which completely undermines the so-called commitment to social mix
column10: or is social mix only to be on public sites?

column2: I offer my sympathy and condolences to the parents and brother of the late Denise Crowley who tragically lost her life in Glenflesk village last Friday evening. The Minister for Transport
column3: Tourism and Sport
column4: Deputy Shane Ross
column5: is progressing a road traffic Bill through the Dáil. He says it is for the safety of road users rather than making a name for himself. However
column6: I ask him
column7: through the Taoiseach
column8: to ensure that the speed limit reductions which have been promised for places such as Glenflesk village and many other parts of County Kerry for the past nine years take place sooner rather than later and before more lives are lost. column9: myself included
column10: have been asking for it for the past nine years?

column2: as did many others

column4: it would need to be an independent review carried out by an independent person and not an internal Civil Service review.Has he had time to reflect on that point? Is he now proposing that an independent person will head up that review?

column1: #LeoVaradkar	unknown-#LeoVaradkar-party	unknown-#LeoVaradkar-dob	unknown-#LeoVaradkar-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2017-12-05 00:00:00	Leaders' Questions	94	I have had time to reflect on it. column4: we are going to commission an independent senior counsel to carry out the review into why the emails were not sent to the tribunal. We expect to be able to release the name of the person who will carry out that review in the next couple days.

column12: services for families and young people and physical improvements. The board implemented a number of proposals across the four priority headings in 2015 at a cost of €2.5 million. This is in addition to the range of local measures implemented in 2016
column13: which were worth approximately €5 million. Further measures will be developed and supported in 2018
column14: with funding of €2.5 million set to be provided through the RAPID programme. To ensure the wider community is involved in the process
column15: the first in a series of community consultation events took place in Larkin community centre on 19 October. We have also confirmed our full commitment to reopening Fitzgibbon Street Garda station following a programme of refurbishment works for which a planning application has been made. We are also fully behind the development of a community hub on the Rutland Street school site. This is being overseen by Dublin City Council
column16: which is finalising costs. Examples of other specific projects that have been delivered include new and refurbished sporting facilities; new outreach workers targeting street dealing who have been in place since September last; the appointment by the Department of Employment and Social Protection of a full-time case officer dedicated to securing job opportunities from local employers; a new construction skills course
column17: which has run several times and secured employment for local participants; the development of a local project to tackle the major problem of litter and dumping in the area; continued improvements by Dublin City Council to lighting
column18: roads and hoardings; the award of community grants totalling €123
column19: 000 to 40 small local projects; closed circuit television
column20: which is at an advanced stage of approval
column21: to be installed at 13 sites across the north inner city; and a programme of clean-up works under way on local railway bridges and the canal bank in co-operation with Irish Rail.

column1: #LeoVaradkar	unknown-#LeoVaradkar-party	unknown-#LeoVaradkar-dob	unknown-#LeoVaradkar-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2017-12-05 00:00:00	Leaders' Questions	119	I propose to take Questions Nos. 7 to 11 together. column2: including the implementation of the Action Plan for Jobs 2017 and preparation of a new
column3: more focused action plan for next year; labour market policies
column4: including the implementation of pathways to work and responding to emerging skills pressures; competitiveness and productivity challenges for business; rural affairs and the implementation of the Action Plan for Rural Development; and the development of a roadmap for pensions reform. I expect to see further progress in all these areas in the coming months
column5: building on the measures announced in budget 2018 and brought or being brought through the Houses in legislation
column6: including the Finance Act
column7: Social Welfare Bill and Appropriations Bill. Responsibility for rural affairs policy rests with the Minister for Community and Rural Development. However

column1: #MichaelMartin	unknown-#MichaelMartin-party	unknown-#MichaelMartin-dob	unknown-#MichaelMartin-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2017-12-05 00:00:00	Leaders' Questions	124	It is a year since we were told the new capital investment plan was nearly ready and would run up to 2021. Since then

I was even asked would I agree to the plan for a major piece of infrastructure so that it could get considered. In other words

I am with the other Members of the House on the insecure employment and precarious jobs issue. We are awaiting legislation on that. We were promised it. Income tax returns are not in "alignment"

#RichardBoydBarrett	unknown-#RichardBoydBarrett-party	unknown-#RichardBoydBarrett-dob	unknown-#RichardBoydBarrett-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2017-12-05 00:00:00	Leaders' Questions	128	The Taoiseach complained about constraints in terms of capacity to deliver housing but the ICTU report confirms something that most of us know anecdotally. Significant numbers of people who formerly worked in construction will not work in construction because of rampant bogus self-employment and the poor conditions and pay of employment for construction workers. If the Taoiseach wants to deal with capacity problems in housing construction
column2: he should deal with bogus self-employment

column1: #PatTheCopeGallagher	unknown-#PatTheCopeGallagher-party	unknown-#PatTheCopeGallagher-dob	unknown-#PatTheCopeGallagher-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2017-12-05 00:00:00	Leaders' Questions	129	The Taoiseach has two and a half minutes.

#LeoVaradkar	unknown-#LeoVaradkar-party	unknown-#LeoVaradkar-dob	unknown-#LeoVaradkar-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2017-12-05 00:00:00	Leaders' Questions	130	Deputies will be pleased to hear that this morning the Minister for Employment Affairs and Social Protection
column2: Deputy Regina Doherty
column3: received approval from Cabinet to publish the employment (miscellaneous provisions) Bill. The Bill will be published in the next few days. It delivers on the programme for Government commitment to tackle some of the problems caused by casualisation of work and to strengthen the regulation of precarious work. The key objective of this important legislation is to improve security and predictability of working hours for employees on insecure contracts and those with variable hours and to outlaw zero-hour contracts in most cases. Cabinet approval for that Bill was granted this morning and we expect the Minister
column4: Deputy Regina Doherty
column5: will publish it in the next few days. Some of the commentary and analysis regarding changes to work patterns is not fully borne out by the facts. In the last number of quarters
column6: the number of employees in part-time employment has fallen whereas the number of employees in full-time employment is increasing. That is not surprising. Initially
column7: when a country comes out of a recession
column8: when it comes out of a severe unemployment crisis
column9: new part-time jobs are created and over time those part-time jobs become full time
column10: and that is why the number of part-time jobs is now falling and the number of full-time jobs is now increasing again. We need to bear in mind that part-time work is not necessarily always a bad thing. Some people want to work part time and have their own reasons for doing so. In terms of temporary employment
column11: the most recent statistics show that the percentage of employees in temporary employment stood at 7.2% in 2008. That rose to 8.7% in 2011 and has fallen back to 7.1% in 2016. While the number of temporary employees overall may have increased because there are more people working
column12: the percentage of the workforce in temporary employment is lower than it was eight years ago. That is an important fact for people to be aware of. Similarly
column13: the number of employees who are self-employed is increasing. As employment increases
column14: as the population grows
column15: more people establish their own businesses or professions. The percentage of the total workforce in self-employment was 10.3% in 2008. That rose to 11.3% in 2011 and fell back to 10.4% in 2016. The percentage of the workforce in self-employment is only 0.1% higher than it was eight years ago. These are facts that people need to be aware of. Of course
column16: the numbers are increasing because there are more people in the country and there are more people at work
column17: but the percentage of the workforce who are self-employed
column18: in part-time employment or in temporary employment is not increasing. Being in part-time employment or being self-employed is not a bad thing. In my view
column19: it can be good for many people. There are different ways to deal with the changes in the world of work. Thirty or 40 years ago
column20: people might have hoped to get a job with a company
column21: to be made permanent
column22: to stay working with that company for their entire lives and to have a pension paid for by that company. Work has changed fundamentally in the past 30 or 40 years. I believe most people now in their 20s or 30s will work for a number of different employers. They may be self-employed for a period of time - often by choice
column23: sometimes perhaps not. They will probably work in more than one or two countries. What we need to do is approach that in a modern way. One can try the reaction
column24: which is to try and ban new forms of employment which is not the right way to go
column25: or restrict immigration or restrict people from travelling to take up jobs elsewhere
column26: or one can embrace the fact that economies evolve and societies change and adapt labour laws accordingly
column27: not to ban these new forms of employment but to provide better social protection ensuring that everyone is covered by the social insurance system. That is why we have extended so many benefits to the self-employed that were not there previously. It is also why we want to bring in auto-enrolment for pensions to ensure that everyone pays in to a pension fund and can carry that pension fund with him or her as he or she moves from job to job
column28: in and out of employment and self-employment and from country to country.
